channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. and China Reach Climate Deal After Months of Talks
item.description: The deal between the nations, the world’s No. 1 and No. 2 carbon polluters, is viewed as essential to concluding a new global accord on climate change.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China held a news conference at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: App City: Two Apps Focus on Public Need in New York
item.description: With Heatseek NYC and Tug, two noteworthy apps that recently won competitions, developers turned their attention to the public need.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH BROMWICH
item.media:credit: Christoph Hitz for The New York Times

item.title: Small Labels and YouTube Enter Deal on Licensing
item.description: YouTube has been developing features that would preserve its free model, but also give paying subscribers more extensive access to music.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SISARIO

item.title: Obama’s Call for Net Neutrality Sets Up Fight Over Rules
item.description: Virtually everyone agrees that some rules written to regulate telephone service should not apply to the Internet but there are disagreements about what rules should survive.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WYATT
item.media:description: President Obama has urged Tom Wheeler, right, chairman of the F.C.C., to reclassify broadband Internet service to treat it more like a utility.

item.title: Bits Blog: Yahoo Buys BrightRoll, a Video Ad Platform, for $640 Million
item.description: The purchase, which had been rumored for weeks, was the Internet company’s largest acquisition since it bolstered its coffers with $6.3 billion from the Alibaba initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: By VINDU GOEL
item.media:description: Marissa Mayer, Yahoo’s chief executive, speaking in April at the NewFronts, an advertising industry event. Ms. Mayer said on Tuesday that BrightRoll would “dramatically strengthen” Yahoo’s video advertising platform.

item.title: Chief Defends Spotify After Snub by Taylor Swift
item.description: The decision by Ms. Swift to remove her entire catalog from Spotify has intensified a debate over royalties paid by streaming music services.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SISARIO
item.media:description: Taylor Swift in September. She has removed all her music from Spotify. Her new album, “1989,” sold nearly 1.3 million copies in its first week.

item.title: Bits Blog: European Antitrust Regulators to Hold Discussions With Google’s Rivals
item.description: The European Union’s competition commissioner wants to hear what companies most concerned about Google’s practices have to say before resolving a longstanding antitrust case.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Jens Noergaard Larsen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager, Europe's new antitrust chief, in September. Google has faced an increasing barrage of criticism in Europe over privacy.

item.title: Bits Blog: Google Chromecast Adds Games
item.description: Google’s Chromecast streaming device now has the ability to let people play video games in tandem.
item.dc:creator: By CONOR DOUGHERTY
item.media:description: Google’s Chromecast allows people to stream content from their mobile phones and tablets onto TVs.

item.title: Bits Blog: For Online Retailers Like Alibaba, Singles’ Day in China Is a Bonanza
item.description: On Singles’ Day, Chinese Internet users showed just how ingrained online shopping has become in the country.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL MOZUR and SHANSHAN WANG
item.media:description: Tmall employees working in Hangzhou, China, early on Tuesday. Singles’ Day is crucial for many small- and medium-size retailers in China.

item.title: State of the Art: In Net Neutrality Push, Internet Giants on the Sidelines
item.description: Companies like Facebook and Google have stayed away from mobilizing their users to support an issue that primarily affects smaller Internet upstarts.
item.dc:creator: By FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Economic Scene: Net Neutrality Debate: Internet Access and Costs Are Top Issues
item.description: After President Obama urged the F.C.C. to set tougher net neutrality rules, questions loom about decreased competition and the cost of monitoring.
item.dc:creator: By EDUARDO PORTER

item.title: DealBook: Juniper Networks Changes Its Chief, Again
item.description: Juniper said that its chief executive resigned following a review by the company’s board into his handling of negotiations with an unnamed customer, as well as his general leadership.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

item.title: Alibaba and Others Push to Improve Delivery, on Singles’ Day in China
item.description: The country’s largest Internet merchants are working to improve logistics in China, a country plagued by delivery inefficiency.
item.dc:creator: By SHANSHAN WANG and PAUL MOZUR

item.title: DealBook: Welsh Carson Leads $100 Million Investment in Revel Systems
item.description: The private equity firm is taking a small equity stake in a start-up that makes point-of-sale payment software for retailers, restaurants and grocery stores.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM ALDEN
item.media:description: Lisa Falzone, the chief executive and co-founder of Revel Systems.

item.title: DealBook: GoPro and Its Founder to Sell More Shares 5 Months After I.P.O.
item.description: GoPro is hoping to circumvent a lockup period by working with shareholders to sell stock in a managed offering
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED
item.media:description: An image taken by a GoPro Hero4 Silver camera.

item.title: Bits Blog: GitHub Hits the Cloud
item.description: The popular method of creating software says its business version will be available for direct use on the most popular public cloud.
item.dc:creator: By QUENTIN HARDY

item.title: Bits Blog: Oops! Health Insurer Exposes Member Data
item.description: Anthem Blue Cross, one of the largest health insurers in California, inadvertently sent emails to some members with demographic and health information in the subject lines.
item.dc:creator: By NATASHA SINGER
item.media:description: An email from Anthem Blue Cross, which contained personal information in the subject line, encouraged members to visit their doctors for check ups and to discuss certain medical screening tests.

item.title: U.S. and China Overcome Hurdles on Technology Pact
item.description: An agreement to cut tariffs on an array of technology products is likely to be the most tangible economic outcome of President Obama’s visit to China.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Sirius XM Adds Show Based on Popular Dance Songs on YouTube
item.description: “The YouTube EDM 15” will highlight trending electronic dance music and will be the second show by the satellite radio service based on YouTube data.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SISARIO

item.title: Bits Blog: Groupon, Too, Turns to Multiple Apps
item.description: The daily deals company released Getaways, an app focused on travel and hotel deals.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE ISAAC
item.media:description: Getaways, a stand-alone mobile app from Groupon to help people find travel packages at discounted rates.

item.title: With ‘High Maintenance,’ Vimeo Invests in Original Content
item.description: Vimeo, a video-sharing web service built to appeal to fans of higher-quality content than sites like YouTube, is directly funding an original series for the first time and hoping viewers will be willing to pay for it.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH BROMWICH
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kerry Trainor, Vimeo’s chief executive, at the website’s office in New York. He says the service caters to higher-quality creators.

item.title: Obama Asks F.C.C. to Adopt Tough Net Neutrality Rules
item.description: President Obama’s comments were his most direct effort to keep cable and telephone companies from providing special access to some content providers.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WYATT

item.title: For Guccifer, Hacking Was Easy. Prison Is Hard.
item.description: Marcel-Lehel Lazar, whose pseudonym celebrated “the style of Gucci and the light of Lucifer,” rampaged through the email of rich Americans, showing the ease of going rogue online.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marcel-Lehel Lazar, a.k.a Guccifer, tormented various celebrities with no special skills beyond what he had picked up on the web.

item.title: Postal Service Discloses Major Theft of Its Employees’ Personal Data
item.description: The agency told employees that an attack “potentially compromised” databases containing names, addresses, birth dates and Social Security numbers.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Rafael Matos sorts mail in Chicago in 2012. The Postal Service told its employees that an attack “potentially compromised” databases containing their names, birth dates, addresses and Social Security numbers.

item.title: Bits Blog: Apple Releases Web Tool for iPhone Switchers
item.description: A new web tool allows former iPhone users to deregister their phone numbers from Apple’s proprietary messaging service, iMessage.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: Apple advises those who still have an iPhone but plan on switching to something else to turn iMessage off in the phone’s settings first.
